title: Entry-Level Wage Impact from AI by 2030
description: Projected change in real wages for entry-level positions (0-2 years experience) across AI-exposed industries by 2030.

overlays.label: Anthropic CEO: up to 50% of entry-level office jobs impacted
Dallas Fed: young worker share fell 16.4% → 15.5%
ILO review: declining demand for novice workers
Stanford: small positive wage effects overall
SSRN: junior employment declined sharply at AI-adopting firms
Frank et al.: unemployment risk rose in AI-exposed occupations from early 2022
Althoff & Reichardt: AI simplification boosts lower-skill worker productivity
Dallas Fed: AI exposure → 0.28pp wage growth reduction in low-experience-premium jobs

sources.title: Entry-Level Job Market Update — Indeed Hiring Lab
sources.excerpt: Entry-level job postings in AI-exposed fields declined 12% YoY. Starting salaries for junior analysts, associates, and coordinators showed early downward pressure.

sources.title: Artificial Intelligence, Automation and Work
sources.excerpt: Theoretical framework for automation's displacement and productivity effects on labor. Automation displaces workers from tasks they previously performed, but productivity gains create new tasks and increase demand for labor.

sources.title: Goldman Sachs economist warns Gen Z tech workers are first on the chopping block
sources.excerpt: Unemployment rate for 20- to 30-year-olds in tech rose nearly 3% since early 2024. Entry-level job postings in the US diminished about 35% since January 2023. Goldman Sachs predicts AI will displace about 6-7% of the total workforce.

sources.title: To prepare young people for the AI workplace, focus on the fundamentals
sources.excerpt: Whether AI destroys jobs or transforms them, young people still need fundamental supports: skill-building, career navigation, and mentorship.

sources.title: Applying AI to Rebuild Middle Class Jobs
sources.excerpt: AI could enable a larger set of workers to perform higher-stakes decision-making tasks currently reserved for elite experts. If used well, AI can help restore the middle-skill, middle-class heart of the US labor market.

sources.title: Entry-Level Jobs Are Vanishing — and AI Is a Big Reason
OECD Youth Employment Outlook 2025
sources.excerpt: Youth (18-24) employment in OECD countries in AI-exposed sectors declined 4.5% YoY. Real starting salaries fell 3-8% across knowledge-work sectors.

sources.title: Usual Weekly Earnings — Workers 16-24
sources.excerpt: Real median weekly earnings for workers aged 16-24 in professional services fell 5.2% from 2023 to 2025.

sources.title: Generative AI and the future of work in America
sources.excerpt: By 2030, activities accounting for up to 30% of hours currently worked could be automated, accelerated by generative AI. Lower-wage workers face up to 14x more occupational transitions than higher-wage counterparts.

sources.title: AI could make half of all entry-level white-collar jobs vanish, Anthropic CEO warns
sources.excerpt: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei warned that up to 50% of entry-level office jobs could be substantially impacted by AI within the next 2-3 years.

sources.title: Canaries in the Coal Mine? Six Facts about the Recent Employment Effects of AI
sources.publisher: Stanford Digital Economy Lab (Brynjolfsson, Chandar, Chen)
sources.excerpt: ADP payroll data shows 13% relative decline in employment for ages 22-25 in most AI-exposed occupations. Effects concentrated in automation roles, not augmentation.

sources.title: Bridging Skill Gaps for the Future: New Jobs Creation in the AI Age
sources.excerpt: Emerging evidence that generative AI adoption is reducing entry-level hiring, especially where tasks are automatable rather than complementary to humans.

sources.title: Labor Demand in the Age of Generative AI: Early Evidence from the U.S. Job Posting Data
sources.excerpt: Job postings for high-AI-substitution occupations fell 12% relative to low-substitution roles post-ChatGPT; effect grew from 6% in year one to 18% by year three. Based on 285 million Lightcast job postings.

sources.title: The Labor Market Effects of Generative Artificial Intelligence
sources.publisher: Stanford / World Bank (Hartley, Jolevski, Melo, Moore)
sources.excerpt: 35.9% of US workers used generative AI by December 2025; adoption concentrated among younger, college-educated workers. Small positive wage effects overall.

sources.title: Young workers' employment drops in occupations with high AI exposure
sources.excerpt: Employment share of young workers (20-24) in most AI-exposed occupations fell from 16.4% to 15.5%; decline driven by fewer people transitioning into employment, not layoffs.

sources.title: AI, Productivity, and Labor Markets: A Review of the Empirical Evidence
sources.excerpt: Pressure concentrated in entry-level segments of highly exposed occupations; adjustment happening at the margin through task reallocation.

sources.title: AI and jobs: A review of theory, estimates, and evidence
sources.excerpt: Novice workers benefit more from LLMs in simple tasks but face declining demand across AI-complementary work; digital trace data show substitution in writing and translation.

sources.title: Seniority-Biased Technological Change: Evidence from AI-Adopting Firms
sources.excerpt: Analysis of 62M U.S. resumes: junior employment declined sharply at AI-adopting firms while senior employment was largely unchanged — described as 'seniority-biased technological change.'

sources.title: Task-Specific Technical Change and Comparative Advantage
sources.excerpt: increases the relative productivity of lower-skill workers in tasks and occupations that were previously the territory of higher skilled workers... this lowering of skill-based barriers is the key force reducing inequality

sources.title: AI Exposure and Unemployment Risk
sources.excerpt: Unemployment risk in AI-exposed occupations rose beginning early 2022; graduates with AI-exposed curricula have higher first-job pay and shorter job searches post-ChatGPT.

sources.title: AI is simultaneously aiding and replacing workers, wage data suggest
sources.publisher: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas (J. Scott Davis)
sources.excerpt: For an occupation with a 0 percent experience premium, increased AI exposure is associated with a 0.28 percentage point reduction in wage growth.
